etymologies: late Middle English (denoting a means of restoration): from Anglo-Norman French recoverie, from recovrer ‘get back’

definitions: a return to a normal state of health, mind, or strength

examples.text: signs of recovery in the housing market
he's back at home now and he looks all set to make a full recovery

shortDefinitions: return to normal state of health or strength

definitions: the action or process of regaining possession or control of something stolen or lost

examples.text: a team of salvage experts to ensure the recovery of family possessions

shortDefinitions: action or process of regaining possession or control of something

definitions: the action of regaining or securing compensation or money lost or spent by means of a legal process or subsequent profits
shortDefinitions: action of regaining or securing compensation or money lost or spent by means of legal process

definitions: an object or amount of money recovered
shortDefinitions: object or amount of money recovered

definitions: a stroke bringing the ball from the rough or from a hazard back on to the fairway or the green.
shortDefinitions: stroke bringing ball from rough or from hazard back on to fairway

definitions: an act of taking possession of a fumbled ball

examples.text: he finished the season with three fumble recoveries and an interception

definitions: (in rowing, cycling, or swimming) the action of returning the paddle, leg, or arm to its initial position ready to make a new stroke

examples.text: I have my heel below the pedal during the power stroke and above it during recovery
the brace is used as a recovery stroke to avoid capsize

shortDefinitions: (in rowing, cycling, or swimming) action of returning paddle, leg, or arm to its initial position ready to make new stroke

definitions: the process of removing or extracting an energy source or industrial chemical for use, reuse, or waste treatment
shortDefinitions: process of removing or extracting energy source or industrial chemical for use
